comments:
Please refer to bugzilla_73471 for more background information.  This defect 
is the result of splitting another defect.  This defect tracks the 
DaemonConnectException being thrown due to an InactiveProcessException being 
thrown.  This defect is hard to reproduce is definitely reproducible.  Not 
sure as the cause of the InactiveProcessException yet (other than the obvious 
of the process not being available within the 30 second timeout).

--Some additional stack traces for the DaemonConnectException, reliable 
reproduction steps are now available for the InactiveProcessException variety 
of this.  Turn on a firwall such as Zone Alarm and then try to launch a test, 
a box will pop up asking if the connection from the agent controller or to the 
agent controller is allowed, wait 10 seconds or more and then just select OK.  
You will then see the DaemonConnectException.  If you check the box to say 
always allow, from that point on it will still not work as if something is 
being cached somewhere, in the execution Java-code or the native-code.  I am 
investigating further.

--Also there is another variety of the DaemonConnectException, if you close 
down your network connection after a test (unplug your network card, for 
example) [I simply closed my laptop while I was in the workbench after a test 
ran] then if you open the connection back up, no more launching of tests is 
possible and a DaemonConnectException triggered by NotConnectedException is 
observed.

bugzilla_80296

Two issues were uncovered, the DaemonConnectException due to an 
InactiveProcessException getting thrown was due to the pid not being
set within 30 seconds (this was the straightforward part).  The
process in question was the session hosting session on the agent
controller machine.  I was unable to make a DaemonConnectException
happen just by exercising typical use cases, I had to force one to
occur by not okaying my firewall (Zone Alarm) to allow the agent
controller to use the network.  After I did this and let the process
launch fail with a DaemonConnectException I took down the firewall
and tried it again, it still didn't work.  It turns out that once
the session hosting process was unable to launch, it could never
launch until the workbench client was restarted (and perhaps the
agent controller as well).  The second problem that was not directly
related to this defect was that the o.e.h.execution.invocation.
Marshaller class had a defect in the removeInstanceFromMap(..) 
method.  It was trying to remove the value via passing the value
instead of the key.  This defect was found while fixing the primary
problem.

This defect was fixed by adding cleanup code to the code blocks
that trap deeper exceptions and cause the DaemonConnectException
to be thrown.  The fix should fix other intermittent problems as
well since proper cleanup was not being done after a session
hosting process launch was unsuccessful (due to a myriad of possible
triggers).

Here is the cleanup code that is now done in NodeImpl.java after
a few possible exceptions are trapped.  There are four cleanup steps
and at least one was very critical [#4] in containing persistent 
DaemonConnectExceptions once one was thrown.  If the connection that
was being used on the node (the node is a hostname qualified singleton)
was not disconnected then once a process inactive exception was thrown
it was always thrown.

1. process.removeProcessListener(processListener);
2. Marshaller.removeInstanceFromMap(((SessionStub)sessionInstance).getUniqueId
());
3. SessionInstance.removeExecutionComponentStateChangeListener
(stateChangeListener);
4. node.getConnection().disconnect();

My thoughts are that something caused the process to not be able to launch
such as a firewall setting or network connection lapse and then after the
problem causing this was resolved, it would still throw a 
DaemonConnectException.
At this point, the problem seemed even larger than it was since proper
cleanup was not being done.  Please open another defect if other unexpected
and incorrect DaemonConnectExceptions are thrown.
